newsitem.title: Indonesia: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - Sept 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - Sept 30.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indonesian political and business stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Jakarta. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (6221) 384-6364. Fax: (6221) 344-8404.
Members of the official National Human Rights Commission say there are no signs of tension or internal friction ahead of a meeting on Tuesday night to elect a new chairman.
Armed Forces Chief General Feisal Tanjung has renewed a warning of a possible communist revival in Indonesia, saying the threat was real, not imaginary as some people claimed.

Around 6,000 members of Moslem organisations marched through Jakarta's streets on Sunday to remember a meeting in October 1965 when Islamic groups gathered to crush the Indonesian Communist Party (PKI) in the wake of a failed coup attempt.
Indonesian experts on Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) have called for greater efforts to control the disease, especially for the protection of women and children.
Businessman Johanes Kotjo almost certainly will take over all the assets and obligations of Bank Summa after it went into liquidation in 1992.
Sources close to the Chandra Asri petro-chemical project say Malaysia's Petronas is ready to take a big share in the giant project.
